summary: A letter from attorney Patrick J. Smith to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the compliance of Jordana H. Feldman, administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program, with a subpoena in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case. The letter requests an extension to produce approximately 6,000-7,000 pages of documents, including claim forms and payment records for four specific individuals.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the Southern District of New York overseeing the United States v. Maxwell case. The letter is addressed to her regarding a subpoena compliance issue.

persons.name: Jordana H. Feldman
persons.role: Independent Administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program
persons.context: The client represented by the letter's author. She was ordered to comply with a subpoena from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense and is working to produce thousands of pages of documents related to victim claims.

persons.name: Patrick J. Smith
persons.context: Attorney at Smith Villazor LLP who authored the letter to Judge Nathan. He represents Jordana H. Feldman and is requesting an extension for document production.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Listed among the prosecutors copied on the correspondence regarding the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Listed among the prosecutors copied on the correspondence regarding the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Listed among the prosecutors copied on the correspondence regarding the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Mark Stewart Cohen
persons.context: Listed among the prosecutors copied on the correspondence regarding the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Stemheim
persons.context: Listed among the prosecutors copied on the correspondence regarding the Maxwell case.

connections.description: Patrick J. Smith, of Smith Villazor LLP, is representing Jordana H. Feldman in her capacity as administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program regarding a subpoena in the Maxwell case.
Judge Nathan issued an order denying Feldman's motion to quash a subpoena and ordering her to produce documents to the court.
Both are listed as Assistant U.S. Attorneys (AUSAs) copied on the legal correspondence, indicating they are part of the prosecution team in United States v. Maxwell.

events.title: Court Denies Motion to Quash Subpoena
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issued an order denying Jordana H. Feldman's motion to quash a subpoena from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense and ordered production of subpoenaed documents by November 24, 2021, at noon.

events.title: Deadline for Initial Document Production
events.description: The court-ordered deadline for Jordana H. Feldman to produce subpoenaed documents from the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program to the court.

events.title: Original Subpoena Return Date
events.description: The original date (8:30 AM) by which documents were to be produced in response to Ghislaine Maxwell's subpoena to the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program administrator.

locations: 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
250 West 55th Street, 30th Floor, New York, NY 10019
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense subpoenaed documents from the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program, administered by Jordana H. Feldman.
The volume of potentially responsive materials is approximately 6,000 to 7,000 pages.
The subpoena specifically sought documents related to four identified individuals, including their claim forms, narratives, payment records, and releases.
The administrator initially moved to quash the subpoena, but the motion was denied by Judge Nathan.
The letter requests an extension to complete production by the original subpoena return date of November 29, 2021.
